No smartwatch has gotten as much attention as the Apple Watch, given Apple's devoted fan base and the company's knack for designing products consumers can't live without.

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch: reviewers
entry.summary:
(Reuters) - Apple Inc's (AAPL.O) "beautiful" and "stylish" smartwatch could make life easier for people on the move, reviewers say, but the gadget gets poor marks for battery life and slow-loading apps.

Reviews published on Wednesday made much of the device's relatively poor battery life - up to 18 hours, according to Apple - and said its apps will need upgrades to load more quickly.

Loading an app required the watch to pull tremendous amounts of data from iPhones, Patel said, adding that Apple had told him upcoming software updates would address performance issues.

Analysts at Societe Generale said they expected Apple to sell 8 million watches in 2015, contributing about 1.7 percent or $4 billion to Apple's total sales.

Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"The Apple Watch is cool, it's beautiful, it's powerful and it's easy to use. But it's not essential. Not yet."

As Manjoo concluded: "The first Apple Watch may not be for you -- but someday soon, it will change your world."

But, he said, "the Apple Watch isn't quite the gatekeeper to my digital life that I wanted. Take app alerts -- there's a fine line between being in the know and having your wrist jiggle all day."

entry.title: Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"After using it, I had no question that the Apple Watch is the most advanced piece of wearable technology you can buy today," Bloomberg's Josh Topolsky wrote.

But, according to New York Times tech columnist Farhad Manjoo, while he generally liked the Apple Watch after a "steep" learning curve, the third-party apps available for the device are "mostly useless right now."

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch-reviewers

entry.title: Reviews are in: Apple Watch performs well but isn't a necessity
entry.summary:
Yahoo Tech: "Once you get to know the Watch, you realize that Apple carefully observed its rivals' failures, and adjusted its product accordingly."

CNET: "The Apple Watch is the most ambitious, well-constructed smartwatch ever seen, but first-gen shortfalls make it feel more like a fashionable toy than a necessary tool."

entry.title: Early Apple Watch reviews are mixed
entry.summary: Wall Street Journal: "After over a week of living with Apple's latest gadget on my wrist, I realized the company isn't just selling some wrist-worn computer, it's selling good looks and coolness, with some bonus computer features. Too many features that are too hard to find, if you ask me."

CNET's Stein said Apple wants people to see the Apple Watch as "fine jewelry."

Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
Apple Pay has taken the United States by storm since its launch in September, and the company has said it already accounts for around $2 out of every $3 spent using "contactless" payments on the three big U.S. card networks.

Unlike the consumer electronics business where Apple regularly rolls out new computers or phones in dozens of countries at once, there is no such thing as a unified payments market.

Apple Pay allows consumers using new Apple phones, tablets and smartwatches to buy goods by simply holding the device up to readers installed by store merchants.

Meanwhile, major banks are looking to offer "mobile wallet" payment apps of their own, using some of the same security technology popularized by Apple.

entry.title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
"Apple doesn't need blanket coverage to start," Morgan Stanley's Humphrey said.

"Apple Pay is available in the U.S.," the official site simply states.

Credit card companies such as Visa and MasterCard - which provided crucial early backing to Apple Pay and are gearing up to support its international expansion - are also looking to hedge their bets and back viable alternatives.

Analysts say Apple is likely to go after markets where iPhones are already popular and where wireless payment readers using technology on which Apple relies are widely available.

entry.title: Apple, Google, Microsoft cop tax audit
entry.summary:
Technology giants Apple, Google and Microsoft have told the federal inquiry into corporate tax avoidance that they are being audited by the tax office for alleged tax avoidance.

entry.title: Snowden: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade
entry.summary:
Efforts to break into Apple products by government security researchers started as early as 2006, a year before Apple introduced its first iPhone and continued through the launch of the iPad in 2010 and beyond, The Intercept said.

Last September, Apple strengthened encryption methods for data stored on iPhones, saying the changes meant the company no longer had any way to extract customer data on the devices, even if a government ordered it to with a search warrant.

An apple a day might keep the pharmacist away: study
entry.summary:
And at first blush, apple eaters seemed more likely to keep the doctor away, with fewer self-reported visits to health care providers.

Limitations of the study include its reliance on self-reports of apple consumption, doctor visits and prescriptions.

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
That's according to proverb-busting research that found daily apple eaters had just as many doctor visits as those who ate fewer or no apples.

Apple eaters were slightly less likely to use prescription drugs, but the study lacks information on use of over-the-counter medication and alternative medicine.

Apples are a good source of vitamin C; one medium apple has about 100 calories and provides nearly 20 percent of the daily recommended amount of fiber.

But, said Dr. Steven Zeisel, director of the University of North Carolina's Nutrition Research Institute, "One apple isn't going to be enough to make a difference unless it's part of a healthy food pattern."

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
A preliminary analysis found apple eaters had slightly fewer visits than apple avoiders - those who ate less than one daily or no apples.

About 9 percent of adults studied ate the equivalent of at least one small apple daily.

Those who ate less than that were considered apple shunners.

Apple eaters had more education and were less likely to smoke than apple shunners, and fewer of them were white.

entry.title: Will the Apple Watch finally move the needle in the smartwatch industry? Here's why & why not
entry.summary:
The stakes are big for Apple CEO Tim Cook: the watch is the first brand-new Apple product to be launched without legendary co-founder Steve Jobs.

MORE FEATURES THAN RIVALS: Along with email, texts and phone calls, Apple says its watch will present news, health readings and other notifications in creative ways that can be read at a glance.

While affluent consumers might pay that for a watch they can wear for years, or even hand down to their children, it's a lot of money for something that could become outdated if Apple releases a new model every year or so - as it does with smartphones.

Apple is working with outside companies to create more apps; Cook has talked about using the watch as an electronic "key" for hotel doors or even cars.

entry.title: Apple's Tim Cook to donate his wealth - Fortune

entry.title: The last days of Steve Jobs: New biography reveals how ailing Apple CEO invited his successor Tim Cook to watch a sappy football film on the eve of his death and how Bill Gates paid one final visit to talk shop
entry.summary: Cook, who took the reins of Apple in August 2011, less than two months before his mentor's death, described to the authors of the biography the moment Jobs invited him over to his house to offer him the top job.

entry.title: Last days of Steve Jobs: Apple CEO invited Tim Cook to watch Denzel Washington movie week before he died
entry.summary:
Five days after Cook and Jobs' movie night, the co-founder of Apple passed away at his Palo Alto, California, estate from complications from pancreatic cancer.

In an interesting titbit, the book reveals that Jobs' favorite Beatle was John Lennon, and that he reportedly named his company after Beatles' Apple Corps Record.

The two men bonded over how much they both missed Jobs, and Lasseter confided in the new Apple CEO that he still had his late boss' number on his phone.

In the memoir, which was released this week, Tim Cook did not miss an opportunity to take a swipe at the unauthorized Steve Jobs biography by Walter Isaacson, which debuted just weeks after the Apple co-founder's death.

entry.title: Apple stock starts trading as part of Dow today

Apple Inc. was added to the Dow after the market closed Wednesday.

Apple, based in Cupertino, California, has a market value of $748 billion.

entry.title: U.S. poll shows 40 per cent of iPhone owners would buy Apple Watch
entry.summary:
About 40 percent of adult Apple iPhone owners in the United States are interested in buying the company's new Apple Watch, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll.

Discussions about the watch have flooded online social media channels such as Twitter and Facebook since Apple held a splashy event in San Francisco on March 9 to showcase the watch.

Among the conversations relating to the Apple watch during the one-week period, 5.8 per cent of the comments showed an intent to purchase, according to Networked Insights, which analyzes tweets, public Facebook posts and other sources.

entry.title: Nearly 40 percent of iPhone owners interested in Apple Watch: poll
entry.summary:
Social media chatter about the Apple watch was 15 percent positive and 5 percent negative in the week following Apple's event, according to an analysis that the firm Networked Insights conducted for Reuters.

Apple is among several large tech companies looking to jumpstart a new market for "wearable" electronic devices.

entry.title: Nearly 40 percent of iPhone owners interested in Apple Watch: poll
entry.summary:
Owners of the iPhone are a particularly important market for Apple as it launches the new watch, which goes on sale April 24.

Among the iPhone owners, 39 percent were interested in purchasing the Apple watch, including 17 percent describing themselves as very interested.

By contrast, the social conversation for Apple's iPhone 6 during the same week was 5 percent positive and 0 percent negative, according to the analysis.

entry.title: Apple in talks to launch online TV service: Report
entry.summary:
The tech giant is working with programmers to offer a bundled service of about 25 channels anchored by broadcasters like ABC, CBS and Fox, on devices such as Apple TV.

The service will not offer NBC broadcast network and cable channels such as USA and Bravo, after a fallout between Apple and Comcast, parent of NBC and CNBC, the report said.

entry.title: Liking Apple too much a big problem for fund managers
entry.summary:
Yet that devotion for Apple is a problem for Burnham and some other managers of so-called diversified funds like his - they want more Apple than they can buy under self-imposed risk-reducing guidelines that typically have them holding no more than 5% of their assets in any one company.

Burnham and the 174 fund managers like him who hold large stakes of their diversified portfolios in Apple are pulled in two directions: hoping to prevent an unforeseen drop in Apple shares from upending their portfolios, while also benefiting from a company whose shares are up 12% this year so far.

Burham didn't set out to have such a big stake in Apple, he said.

Other fund managers with large stakes in Apple who aren't selling say that they didn't set out to have an oversized position in the company.

David Chiueh, the manager of the Upright Growth fund, has 13.4% in Apple, the second-largest among diversified funds tracked by Lipper, mostly because shares he bought in 2008 have appreciated, he said.

entry.title: Apple Watch may be a tough sell with Americans: 69% not interested in buying the gadget, new poll shows

entry.title: 3 reasons Apple's watch will _ or won't _ change the game

Is the Apple Watch going to be able to do the same?

Here are three reasons the Apple Watch will finally move the needle in the smartwatch industry - and three reasons it might not.

A recent Forrester survey found some respondents didn't see a reason to buy one because they already owned a less-expensive fitness band or a full-featured smartphone (although it also found Apple fans ready to buy the new watch).
